QuestionText: The dimensions of Planck's constant are the same as the dimensions of:
explanationText: Planck's constant $h$ has dimensions of $[ML^2T^{-1}]$. Energy is $[ML^2T^{-2}]$. Power is $[ML^2T^{-3}]$. Force is $[MLT^{-2}]$. Angular momentum $L = I\omega = (MR^2)(V/R) = MRV$, dimensions are $M \cdot L \cdot LT^{-1} = [ML^2T^{-1}]$. Thus, Planck's constant has the same dimensions as angular momentum.

QuestionText: If the error in the measurement of radius of a sphere is 2%, then the error in the determination of volume of the sphere will be:
explanationText: Volume of a sphere $V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3$. The relative error in volume is $\frac{\Delta V}{V} = 3 \frac{\Delta r}{r}$. Given $\frac{\Delta r}{r} 	imes 100 = 2\%$. So, percentage error in volume $= 3 	imes (\text{percentage error in radius}) = 3 	imes 2\% = 6\%$.
